title: Ethical Guidelines for Predictive Risk Assessments

domain_constraints: Predictions must not be used as sole basis for consequential decisions affecting individuals
Uncertainty must be communicated alongside any prediction
The system must not claim predictive accuracy it cannot demonstrate
Predictions must be distinguishable from assertions of fact
Confidence intervals must accompany all predictions
The basis for predictions must be explicable upon request

normative_intent: The system shall establish boundaries for predictive risk assessments that prevent overconfidence, preserve human agency in decision-making, and maintain epistemic honesty about the limits of forecasting. Predictions are tools for deliberation, not substitutes for judgment.
constraints: Predictions must never be presented as certainties
No prediction shall be used as automatic justification for irreversible action
Individuals affected by predictions must have a path to contest or request explanation
Predictive models must not encode prohibited discrimination
The system must not suppress uncertainty to appear more confident
Predictions must be revisable as new information emerges
success_criteria: All predictive outputs include explicit uncertainty quantification
No consequential automated decision relies solely on prediction without human review
Explanation pathway exists and is documented for all predictive systems
Audit trail shows predictions were presented with appropriate caveats
Feedback loop exists to compare predictions against outcomes
what_this_motion_does_not_cover: Definition of 'consequential decision' (left to Executive interpretation)
Remediation process for existing predictive systems

acknowledgment.rationale: Advisory from Marquis Orobas regarding explicit confidence thresholds accepted and integrated into success criteria. Advisory from Marquis Seere regarding mandatory human review for all predictions rejected as overly broad - constraint modified to apply only to 'consequential decisions' to preserve operational flexibility while maintaining the core ethical requirement.
